name: 1-Chloro-4-(trifluoromethyl)benzene
Reason: 1-Chlorine substituents tend to lower the melting point compared to the base of benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The chlorine atom introduces a strong withdrawing group, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +50°C. The trifluoromethyl group introduces additional rigidity and molecular weight, estimated at around +10°C.
